job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Good pay, good benefits, good PTO
cons: If you are working in operations, don't count on job security or even basic human rights. You can't even go to the bathroom without scrutiny. If you are working elsewhere it might not be so bad, but Wells Fargo is so hard to do business with. They are such a high friction company, and what I mean by that is that it takes 4 forms and a blood sample to link a brokerage account and a bank account. It takes a minimum of 14 business days to have a simple transfer-on-death account reviewed, only for it to be rejected 90% of the time for the littlest thing. Usually something along the lines of putting a middle name when they only needed a middle initial. Everything is an extreme process, that gets handled by teams that would rather reject it than help you complete it.

review_title: Good company at first, empty promises start to show
job_title: Personal Banker I in New York, NY
pros:
Retirement plan is good but they just transferred it over to Empower
You get great employee benefits and amazing PTO time
You get a discounted rate if you need to take a loan out from your retirement
Long maternity leave
cons: If you plan on moving up there are many empty promises even if you put in the work. We were given a chance to work remote temporarily for 4 months and they had announced it would be for Business PPP loans. I agreed to transfer roles from Personal Banker so I would have more exposure in that thinking it would be a temporary position that would last a few months. We go through training and it turns out they transferred us to a regular call center for customer service having nothing to do with PPP loans. It was a way for Wells Fargo to remove personal bankers and make room for more licensed bankers. Prior to my decision to work remote I was waiting to start my licensed banker training and the district manager had announced they removed sponsoring the license. Now I am stuck working in the call center within Wells Fargo and have all this PTO time that is impossible to schedule within a call center and there are no holiday hours because the call center is available 24/7. I wasn’t the only Personal Banker that this happened to and several others were tricked into thinking it would be a temporary position to enhance our skills in Business. It was described as such by our District manager- and the licensed bankers who applied were the only people who were able to return from the “temporary position” they were all called back in to their branches. When bankers started speaking up and we all communicated in training that this wasn’t what we signed up for they “escalated” it to HR and we’ve heard nothing since. The unfortunate part of this all is that call center locations are located in more rural areas and there is no call center in the state I am in. So what’s going to happen to us that are not physically located near these call centers when everything opens up? Remote work is not going to be forever especially as a call center representative. I believe by then they will weed us out instead of furloughing us or firing us because the company wasn’t doing well during COVID this is the tactic they used to displace us slowly since they didn’t want any bad media for what they are doing to us. I wish they had just let us go before because we would have received unemployment benefits at the time since we didn’t receive any bonus for working during covid as essential workers. They will end up giving us an ultimatum as things begin to reopen- either quit or move to the state where the call center location is open to resume work. We’ll see how this scheme of theirs goes!

pros: Wells Fargo really works with their people and trains from the ground up
cons:
Corporate takes WAY to long to hire anyone. There is no help, customers are angry about the long wait times and they take it out on the staff who are trying their absolute best. 

You only get a 30 minute break, even if you work 8 hours. Normally you get two 15 minute breaks and a 30, but since there is no one to cover - you don't get to take a break from nasty, rude, and condescending customers.

You are expected to keep smiling and say things perfectly and with the perfect tone, or you will get disciplined. Staff is absolutely pushed to their breaking point with no understanding from managers or breaks to cool off from tough interactions.

If you get it wrong - don't be surprised that you are blamed for the entire interaction (even if the customer started off in a foul mood) and then shamed for not being perfect 100% of the time. I understand being good to the customer, but with no breaks, long lines out the door, rude and nasty customers, and managers who refuse to see their staff at their boiling point - yeah you are not going to have a perfect customer interaction every single time.
